total.title: GHG emissions are changing our climate and choking our world
total.summary: Global temperatures are linked to the concentration of greenhouse gases (GHG) in our atmosphere and we are heading for a catastrophic rise in excess of 3°C this century. To limit this to 1.5°C, we need to cut emissions by 30 gigatones annually by 2030. That means cutting emissions from transport and industry, managing land and resources more efficiently, building smart cities and curbing deforestation and food waste.
total.annotation: Each square represents a country, scaled by its emissions

percapita.title: Our individual carbon footprints vary wildly; wealth is a key factor
percapita.summary: The wealthiest 1 per cent of the global population produce more than twice the emissions of the poorest 50 per cent. As developing countries grow their economies, they need financial assistance and technical support to transition to low-carbon, resilient strategies. It is possible to reduce emissions and grow economies. For example the energy sector can cut emissions by 12.5 gigatonnes annually by switching to renewable energy and being more efficient with the power it consumes.

trend.title: Some countries are making progress but all nations need to step up
trend.summary: In 2019, total GHG emissions, including land-use change, reached a new high of 59.1 GtCO2e. This is far above what is needed to achieve the 2015 Paris Agreement goals of limiting global warming to well below 2°C and pursuing 1.5°C. The good news is that the technologies already exist, including renewable power, green hydrogen and modern bioenergy. The COVID-19 crisis offers a chance to direct recovery measures towards low-carbon, green policies.

surface.title: Rising land temperatures reinforce need for urgent action
surface.summary: The earth’s mean near-surface temperature has risen by more than 1°C compared to the pre-industrial era and, at current rates, this will reach 1.5°C by around 2040 and possibly earlier. To turn this around, we all need to implement lifestyle changes, provide financial and technical assistance for developing nations, and support for nature-based solutions, like reforestation.
surface.short-summary: The earth’s mean near-surface temperature has already risen by more than 1°C compared to the pre-industrial era.

annotation.text: Between 1980 and 2010, Madagascar was struck by 35 cyclones and floods, five periods of severe droughts, five earthquakes and six epidemics, threatening the uniquely diverse flora and fauna of the island.

In Arctic Siberia, rising temperatures have caused intense wildfires across the region’s boreal forests and tundra. When the tundra, which is a carbon sink, burns it releases more carbon emissions than burning forests.
India has suffered increasingly frequent and extreme heatwaves since the start of the century. In 2015, over 2,400 people died in a heatwave and such events have become more common.
In Uttarakhand, in the Himalayas, a deadly flood, caused by a breaking glacier, killed around 140 people in 2021. Global warming will cause mountain temperatures to rise twice as fast as the average.

Over the last 20 years, California experienced more years of drought than it did without drought. The most severe period, between January 2014 and January 2017, led to a severe water deficit in both the soil and underground aquifers.
The northernmost inhabited Arctic town, Longyearbyen on the Norwegian archipelago of Svalbard, saw a new record temperature of 21.7°C on 25 July 2020, compared to a July average of 5.9°C.

ocean.title: Our oceans are getting warmer and sea levels are rising
ocean.summary: Ice sheets and glaciers are melting, pushing sea levels higher and threatening coastal cities and settlements. Rising sea levels mean storm surges will be deadlier. Carbon dioxide emissions also lead to ocean acidification, which harms marine species, including corals. And things could get worse: as the world gets hotter, it is more likely the Arctic will be ice-free in summer, further disrupting ocean circulation and ecosystems.
ocean.short-summary: Ice sheets and glaciers are melting, pushing sea levels higher and threatening coastal cities and settlements.

annotation.text: In September 2020, Arctic sea ice shrank to the second-lowest extent ever recorded (3.709 million square kilometres). A Siberian heatwave accelerated the ice retreat along the Arctic Russian coast, in particular from late June.

In March 2020, Australia’s Great Barrier Reef, home to the world’s largest collection of coral reefs, suffered a third mass coral bleaching event in five years due to increasingly warmer temperatures, recorded in February.

fire.title: Wildfires raise spectre of terrifying new normal in hotter world
fire.summary: Huge wildfires in Australia, the Amazon, California, the Congo basin and even in the Arctic are sobering reminders of the human, economic and environmental costs of climate change. Record temperatures, heatwaves and droughts help spark wildfires. The global average temperature is now around 1.1°C higher than at the beginning of last century, meaning wildfires and megafires could become a new normal in some countries.
fire.short-summary: Wildfires in Australia, the Amazon, California, or the Congo basin are sobering reminders of costs of climate change.

annotation.text: In Australia, the 2019-2020 wildfire season was the worst on record, burning 18.3 million hectares by mid-January, causing loss of life, homes, livelihoods and the reported deaths of a billion animals.

In the western United States, following record-breaking high temperatures in August 2020, lightning strikes from severe thunderstorms ignited fires in California, Oregon and Washington, consuming 2 million hectares and leaving at least 40 people dead.

In Arctic Siberia, exceptional and prolonged heat fuelled unprecedented fires during the summer of 2020. Satellite images from Europe's Sentinel 3 showed that the wildfires covered a width of about 800 kilometres.

In 2015, massive wildfires ravaged Indonesia, scorching 2.6 million hectares and producing a toxic haze that blanketed neighboring Singapore and Malaysia. Indonesia suffered $16 billion in economic losses, according to the World Bank. Fires set to clear land often spiral out of control, particularly during the dry season.

Canada suffered the worst wildfire season on record in 2018, with 16,000 people evacuated as 2,117 wildfires filled the skies of western Canada with smoke. Weather was a key driver with late July bringing record-breaking temperatures and severe lightning.

In 2020, Brazil’s Amazon rainforest experienced its worst outbreak of fires in a decade, with blazes increasing 13 per cent in the first nine months compared to 2019. Scientists said the dry season was particularly severe partly because of warming in the tropical North Atlantic Ocean, which pulled moisture away from South America.

ndcs.title: Countries must strengthen pledges made under Paris Agreement
ndcs.summary: Under the 2015 Paris Agreement, governments made pledges, known as Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs), to cut emissions. And although a growing number of countries have  now committed to net-zero emissions, the levels of ambition in the Paris accord must be roughly tripled for the 2°C pathway and increased at least fivefold for the 1.5°C pathway. There is no time to lose.

public.title: Public awareness and concern must catalyze political action
public.summary: Public concern over the climate emergency is rising. In a survey of 26 nations in 2018, the Pew Research Center found that people broadly agree that climate change poses a severe risk to their countries, with populations in 13 nations seeing climate change as the top international threat. However, so far this awareness has not translated into sustained political action on a global scale. This must change.
